Your book probably has a chapter on applications of both differentiation and integration, after the chapter that introduces these concepts.  Some applications of differentiation: 1. Design optimization, finding the minimum and maximum points of a function relating a term we'd like to optimize relative to design constraints/specifications 2. Kinematics, and the way to determine velocity and acceleration given position as a function of time 3. Linear approximation of a difficult-to-calculate function 4. Design of smooth roads and rail paths, so riders of cars and trains can be comfortable  Some applications of integration: 1. Cumulative effects of force distributions, like the force of water on a dam 2. Cumulative effects of time-varying forces, like impulse and work 3. Determining strengths and stiffness of beams supporting a given load as a function of position 4. Calculating probability of a number being in a given range, given a continuous probability density function that governs that number. 5. Center of mass and other mass distribution properties of an exotic shaped object

Both of those examples are only 2-dimensional equations.  You would need a 3-dimensional equation to determine f(x,y).

If we look at the graph, the curve y=x^2 is closer to the y-axis hence being lower while the curve y=2x is farther from the y-axis hence being the upper bound.   Another way of checking that is by putting values in the curve equations. As X runs from 0 to 2, putting 1 in the equations gives lower value on y=x^2 so it is chosen as the lower bound.   Also, if you start from the x-axis and then continue going up to the y-axis, the first line you would hit will be y=x^2 hence that is your lower boundary and the second line you would hit would be y=2x hence that would be your upper boundary.

If we look at the graph, the curve y=x^2 is closer to the y-axis hence being lower while the curve y=2x is farther from the y-axis hence being the upper bound.   Another way of checking that is by putting values in the curve equations. As X runs from 0 to 2, putting 1 in the equations gives lower value on y=x^2 so it is chosen as the lower bound.   Also, if you start from the x-axis and then continue going up to the y-axis, the first line you would hit will be y=x^2 hence that is your lower boundary and the second line you would hit would be y=2x hence that would be your upper boundary.

If we look at the graph, the curve y=x^2 is closer to the y-axis hence being lower while the curve y=2x is farther from the y-axis hence being the upper bound. If we look at the graph, the curve y=x^2 is closer to the y-axis hence being lower while the curve y=2x is farther from the y-axis hence being the upper bound.   Another way of checking that is by putting values in the curve equations. As X runs from 0 to 2, putting 1 in the equations gives lower value on y=x^2 so it is chosen as the lower bound.   Also, if you start from the x-axis and then continue going up to the y-axis, the first line you would hit will be y=x^2 hence that is your lower boundary and the second line you would hit would be y=2x hence that would be your upper boundary.

Plug the equation in to your graphing calculator, and imitate the shape on the screen in your drawing.  If you don't have a graphing calculator, I can recommend using Geogebra in your web browser.  You can also make a table of representative x/y ordered pairs and play "connect the dots" as you mark these points on the plot.   Eventually, you learn typical trends that each family of functions will have, and know how to find turning points, intercepts, asymptotes, domain/range, and other key features of the graph, from analyzing the equation that defines the graph.

@doxo9597  hi

@dinamosflams  I think it would be called hypersurface volume, and hypervolume.  Given a tesseract of side length L, the hypervolume would be L^4.   The hypersurface volume would be 8*L^3.  Given an n-dimensional equivalent of the cube in general, its space occupied its higher dimensional space is given by L^n, and its boundary size would be 2*n*L^(n-1).  For the familiar examples of a square and cube, we can test this as follows: Square (n=2).   Total space is the area, which is L^n, plug in n=2, and get L^2.   Boundary size is called perimeter, which is 2*n*L^(n-1), plug in n=2, and get 4*L for its perimeter.  Cube (n=3).   Total space is the volume, which is L^n, plug in n=3, and get L^3.   Boundary size is called surface area, which is 2*n*L^(n-1), plug in n=3, and get 6*L for its perimeter.
moving in the positive y direction, starting on the x axis, you hit x^2 first, and then 2x.
@ProfessorDaveExplains  than ks

If we look at the graph, the curve y=x^2 is closer to the y-axis hence being lower while the curve y=2x is farther from the y-axis hence being the upper bound.   Another way of checking that is by putting values in the curve equations. As X runs from 0 to 2, putting 1 in the equations gives lower value on y=x^2 so it is chosen as the lower bound.   Also, if you start from the x-axis and then continue going up to the y-axis, the first line you would hit will be y=x^2 hence that is your lower boundary and the second line you would hit would be y=2x hence that would be your upper boundary.

z = f(x,y) = 3x^2-3xy^2. You'd have to look for critical points/saddle points etc. using the gradient vector. Or you can type the equation into wolfram alpha, which will provide you with a 3d model of the surface. From there you can see the surface slopes downwards and at (2,4) you have a local minimum. Knowing this information you can just input the coordinates.  z=f(2,4)=-84 for the lower boundary. z=f(2,0)=12 for the upper boundary <- just using intuition as z will be most positive when y is zero.

24kGoldenRocket I would describe LaTex as the scientific Microsoft Word, it’s like “programming” a document, you have to input the commands instead of picking it on a graphic interphase. Also it support the use of mathematical symbols as the integral one

Yeah, they just become messy expressions because you never insert numbers so it can get out of hand real fast.  To give a supper simple example, consider this definite integral: int[x=0..2]( 2*x ) = 2^2-0^2=4  Compared to the indefinite integral: int (2*x) = x^2  The definite integral gives an area from 0 to 2, the indefinite gives an expression.
